etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in John Palsgrave (d. 1554), teacher and scholar of languages. Apparently from Middle French bonne-grace (French bonne-grâce) ornamental and protective piece of fabric, in various contexts (although this is first attested slightly later: 1548 with reference to the curtain of a bedstead) from bonne, feminine of bon good + grace, probably after collocations such as bonne grace pleasant manner, de bonne grace pretty

definitions: A projecting brim or shade attached to the front of a bonnet or headdress, protecting the wearer's face from the sun. Also figurative and in extended use. Compare "shadow".
